brief_summary.textblock:
The study was performed to assess the effect of PH-797804 on neutrophils (white cells) in
      the sputum after a challenge with an endotoxin (inhaled LPS). Neutrophils are a sign of
      inflammation and PH-797804 is being developed as a potential anti-inflammatory treatment for
      patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).

clinical_study.brief_title: PH-797804 LPS Study in Healthy Volunteers

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy male or female (WONCBP), non atopic volunteers aged 18-50 years

          -  Able to produce sputum

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Current Smokers

          -  Abnormal liver function test

          -  Respiratory Tract Infection within 4 weeks

link.description: To obtain contact information for a study center near you, click here.

clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, 2-way Crossover Study to Determine the Effects of a Single Oral Dose of Ph-797804 on Induced Sputum Inflammatory Markers Following Inhaled Lipopolysaccharide (Lps) Challenge in Healthy Volunteers

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: TNF-α, MIP-1β, IL-6, MPO, MCP-1, GRO-α

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Neutrophil count, GRO-α, TNF-α, MIP-1β, IL-6, MPO, MCP-1, CRP

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Pharmacodynamics Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
